bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to James M. Phalen, January 29, 1943

div1.p: Kean states that his reference to Gorgas' Final Report should not diminish Gorgas' credibility and reputation.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to James M. Phalen, January 29, 1943
div1.opener:
2804 N Street, N.W.
Washington, D. C.
January 29/43.
My dear Colonel Phalen:
div1.p:
At the luncheon on Dec. 15 someone in authority, I
am uncertain whether it was you or Hume, asked me if I had a
copy of the remarks which I was going to make. I said no, only
some notes which were not full enough for publication. You
remember that, after the two Surgeon Generlals McIntyre and
Parran had made their speeches, they got restless nand wanted to
go back to their offices, and Captain Mann thought it best to
suggest that Gen. Russell and I had better simply express our
thanks, so that the proceeding could be brought to an end.
Making speeches is not my long suit anyway, so it was all right
with me, and I imagine Russell felt the same way and so it was
done.

But Hume wrote to me afterwards and asked me to write
out for him from my notes what was in my mind to say and I did
so and sent them to him, I suppose for some writing which he had
in hand. He has now returned to me a fair copy of it, and it has
occurred to me that you might wish to have a copy for the records
of your office, or at any rate might wish to see it - so here it
is. Please return it after reading it and, if you wish to keep
a copy, you might send me an extra carbon. The only value of it
is to make it clear that the citation does not trespass at all on
Gorgas's domain. I do not think that Gorgas's delay in accepting
Reed's findings should be made a matter of criticism of him, and
(as I say) that Gorgas lost nothing in fame or in opportunity
(for advancement) by it. As the citation is signed both by
Captain Mann and by you, it might come in well if any one chose
to be critical.

Gorgas's Final Report which is referred to by me may
be found in the collection of documents relating to the Walter
Reed and Yellow Fever Episode which, under instructions from
the Surgeon General, I collected and had published as Senate
Document No. 822 of the 61st Congress, 2nd Session. It is long
out of print. I think that Gen. Russell got the last copy. No.
Dr. P. S. Hench of the Mayo Foundation dug up positively the
last one at the Capitol 2 years ago.

With all good wishes and much appreciation for what
you and your office have been always willing to do to oblige
me, I am,
div1.closer: Always your friend Sincerely, (Signed) J. R. KEAN COPY
